# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

You can solve this problem in Julia using the DataFrames.jl package which is a powerful package for working with dataframes in Julia. 

Here's how you could approach it:

```julia
using DataFrames, RData

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    filter!(r -> r.manufacturer == "audi" && (r.model == "a4" || r.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    df[:audi_a4_type] = true
    return df
end
```
This function uses the DataFrames.jl `filter!` function to filter rows that have "audi" as their manufacturer and either "a4" or "a4 quattro" as their model, keeping only those rows in our dataframe. 

Then it creates a new column named `:audi_a4_type` set to true for all rows, and finally returns the updated DataFrame.

You can test this function using your data:
```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"], 
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df_cars = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
